transcripts.text: CNN host Breonna Keillor absolutely demolished a Trump White House official, Brian Morgenstern.  And this is over the issue of health care.  Now, I very rarely do this, but I'm going to show you the entire exchange.  There really is no way to edit this down.  It was so well done and it is so rare to see.  And really, I mean... Breonna really shouldn't deserve the credit that she's going to get after I play this clip, because this is kind of what you should expect from the media.  But because it is so rare, I have to show you this.  This is exactly what all media should be doing to the Trump administration, especially on the issue of health care.
Consequences of this vacancy on the direction of the country could be huge, because if you fill this vacancy, Obamacare is likely dead.  So where is your plan to replace it?

So the president has taken a number of steps in the health care space.  I would not agree, by the way, with your premise on hypocrisy, but we have gone through that.  So I'll move on to your health care question.  But with respect to Obamacare, the president is committed to protecting pre-existing conditions.  He's alluded to his executive actions he can do in that regard.  He has also taken a number of steps already on reducing drug prices.  on making different types of plans, more affordable plans available to the American people, like association health plans.  He's made telemedicine more available.  So he is about reducing costs, expanding access, especially with the measures he's already taken.  And he has said in the media in recent weeks that he will have more to say on health care as well.  But he is 100 percent committed to protecting pre-existing conditions.
People are already voting.  Where is the plan?

He has said, I mean, the people can get a pretty good preview of the way the president views health care in this country and on how to expand access and reduce costs because he's taken a number of steps already.  He will take a number of additional steps that you will outline very soon.
Listen, let's listen to what he said less than a week ago.  This is what he said about having a plan ready.

You've been promising a new health care plan.  I interviewed you in June of last year.  You said the health care plan would come in two weeks.  You told Chris Wallace that this summer it would come in three weeks.  You promised an executive order on pre-existing.  I have it already.  But you've been trying to strike down pre-existing conditions.
I have it already, and it's a much better plan for you.
It's already.  That was six days ago.  Where is the plan, Brian?
The president will roll it out when he's ready to do so, but it will focus on expanding access, reducing costs, and it's important to know.

Ryan, it doesn't matter.  Where is the plan?  We're six weeks from the election.  He'll roll it out when he's ready.  People are already voting.  He's been promising this over the summer.  He's been promising this for years.  He's asking the Supreme Court in a moment that it will get soon to get rid of Obamacare.  He has to have something to replace that if he's going to make good on his promises.  Where is the plan?

He has already eliminated the individual mandate.  He has already lowered prescription drug costs.  He has already expanded health care options and insurance options.  He has already expanded telemedicine.  He'll have more to say on the subject very soon.  I understand it's frustrating that...

People with pre-existing condition... No, people... It's... Well, there is no plan.  These are executive orders.  And on the issue of pre-existing conditions, this isn't... When the president is talking about a plan... That seems to be that he's talking about a comprehensive plan.  People are concerned.  You heard this last week from voters.  They're concerned about their pre-existing condition, conditions.  You're looking at an estimated 12 million people during this COVID pandemic.  It becomes increasingly important who may be losing their employer provided insurance.  So where is the plan that they need and that they should have?  if we listen to what the president has said?  Where is the plan?
Well, I appreciate your persistence.  You've now asked me the same question a number of times, and I'll give you the same answer.
I've gotten the answer no times.  I've not actually gotten an answer.  That's why I'm asking again, Brian.

The president will issue a more comprehensive view, but as I've said, you can get a preview already from the many comments that he's made and the many actions he has taken.  He is committed to protecting pre-existing conditions.  He has already lowered costs.  He has already expanded access.
When will he release the plan?
You will release it very soon, Brianna.
He's been promising very soon, and he's blown past his own deadlines.  Before the election?

He will be very soon.  He will be very transparent on this policy, as he is with all of his other policies.  The American people will never have to guess where President Trump stands on a very important issue.
They will certainly have to guess where he stands on this issue.  Let's listen to what he has said over the summer about the timing of his plan.

We're signing a health care plan within two weeks, a full and complete health care plan that the Supreme Court decision on DACA gave me the right to do.  So we're going to solve.  We're going to sign an immigration plan, a health care plan and various other plans.  And nobody will have done what I'm doing in the next four weeks.  I do want to say that we're going to be introducing a tremendous health care plan sometime prior, hopefully prior to the end of the month.  It's just about completed now.  Over the next two weeks, I'll be pursuing a major executive order requiring health insurance companies to cover all pre-existing conditions for all customers.  That's a big thing.
I'll ask you again, Brian, the plan is long overdue.  Why is the plan not out?

Brianna, it'll be out very soon.  I don't know if you expected me to bring it with me here to this interview, but the president will release it on his timeline very soon.  And he, again, will focus on reducing costs, expanding access.

Brian, to be clear, Brian, he put his timeline out there.  That's completely false, what you're saying.  He's not releasing it on his timeline.  He's blown past his timeline.  I mean, is there even a plan?

It's his timeline.  So there is a plan.  He will describe it clearly to the American people.  It will reduce costs and expand access and protect pre-existing conditions.  And the American people will have a very good look at it, and they'll be very pleased with it.

How is he going to protect pre-existing conditions?  With an executive order?  You know that's not how it works.  He can't do that.  He's asking the Supreme Court to get rid of Obamacare, which protects people with pre-existing conditions.

I think some of the best lawyers in the world and in the country have looked at this and helped him with it, and he is very confident that with executive action he'll be able to do that, as he has already publicly stated.

If that were the case, Brian, if that were the case, then Presidents Obama and Clinton wouldn't have gone through that rather pleasant process of going to Congress to get pre-existing conditions protected.  You can't just do that with an executive order.  That's what the experts say.  This is something that requires something more.

I think other experts say differently.  I'm not here to speak for President Obama or Clinton.  I'm here to speak for President Trump and what his lawyers have looked at.  But given the current state of the law, they believe they're on sound footing to do that.  So he will do what it takes to protect pre-existing conditions.  It would obviously be better if we get Congress on a bipartisan basis to help pass a comprehensive health care plan that will do all these things that the president wants.  But to the extent they're not willing to play ball, he will use his authority to expand access, lower costs, and protect pre-existing conditions.

All right, people are already voting.  We are just several weeks here to the election, so we'll be awaiting that plan that is long overdue from the president.  Brian Morgenstern, thanks for being with us.

I think Brian was just happy to get out of there.  That was almost seven minutes.  of Breonna Keillor solidly pushing the Trump White House official on the issue of healthcare, knowing full well that Trump doesn't have a healthcare plan, has never had a healthcare plan, has been saying for years that he has a healthcare plan, has never shown anything, has never presented any healthcare plan.  Before the election, Trump was saying that his healthcare plan, he would have everyone covered.  Under Trump's healthcare plan, everybody would be covered.  Well, Where's the plan?  That was four years ago.  They have no plan.  All they have tried to do is repeal the Affordable Care Act, which, if you know anything about what I do, is not a great plan.  The Affordable Care Act is literally a Republican plan from the 90s.  It is a Heritage Foundation health care plan from the 90s.  It is a private insurance-based health care plan.  That is capitalism 101, tying health care to private insurers for the rest of time.  This is why Trump has never presented a healthcare plan.  Because how further right could he possibly go?  What healthcare plan could he possibly present that would cover pre... Could he possibly present that would cover pre-existing conditions and still guarantee everyone healthcare while also keeping it a private insurance-based system?  What could he possibly do?  That's what Obamacare is.  It is a Republican healthcare plan.  And... Brianna here did everything you should do.  There's only one thing that I would have done extra, and that's I would have brought in the discussion about how far right Obamacare is and what could Trump possibly do and maybe bring up Medicare for all.  But then I guess that'd be getting too into the weeds on on what should actually be done in health care.  And I guess, you know, hosts can't really do that, though they should.  But.  She did everything you're supposed to do here in terms of bringing up clips.  So, you know, credit also goes here to the producers for having this stuff ready.  Those two different Trump clips about Trump saying he's going to have a health care plan in a few weeks.  Brilliant.  This is exactly what you do because it shows you how dishonest the administration is.  They have no plan.  They have never had any plan.  And part of the reason you rarely see this kind of pushback really is because of commercials.  Hosts on television have to worry about time, so they can't just keep going forever.  I guarantee you the only reason they cut off there at about seven minutes is because they had to go to a commercial.  Otherwise, it would go on forever.  And Brianna should try to keep pushing Brian on that question of health care.  But again, their limitations are on... It's all about timing.  And also, I mean... There are other limitations as well in terms of corporate donors.  And this is also very rarely why you see proper analysis on Medicare for all because Medicare for all cuts out private insurance and you see a ton of private insurance commercials on CNN, on MSNBC, on Fox News.  So they very rarely give you the actual straight truth on a single payer system and how beneficial it would be and how awesome it's been in Canada and other countries that have some kind of universal health care system.  But so there's that limitation as well.  But ultimately, look, this is this is exactly what I want to see.  This is what you should expect from journalists.  Again, Brianna Keillor shouldn't get too much credit here because this is just this is what their job is.  But we also have to encourage this.  So, look, if you're on Twitter, send her a message, tell her a good job.  I want to see that more often because this is the kind of thing we should expect out of cable news.
